{{< var course.subtitle >}} author: '{{< var instructor.name >}}' subtitle: Wealth · Scales date: November 04, 2024 date-format: long from: markdown+emoji bibliography: ../../data/lit/wipol_advanced.bib csl: ../../data/lit/wipol.csl execute: freeze: auto echo: true fig-width: 6 fig-height: 5 format: revealjs: theme: ../econpol_slides.scss footer: '{{< var course.number >}} {{< var course.title >}} | {{< var course.semester >}}' logo: ../../data/img/wu-logo-simple.png header-includes: | slide-number: true show-slide-number: all transition: fade progress: true multiplex: false scrollable: false preview-links: false hide-inactive-cursor: true highlight-style: printing pause: true --- # What is wealth and how do we measure it?
![](../../data/img/avatar_leger.png){width=250}
::: footer ::: ## Definition of private wealth {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {style="font-size:1.5rem"} ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Non-financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Dwellings (owner-occupied residence, other real estate) - Consumer durables (vehicles, etc.) - Valuables - Intellectual property ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Currency and deposits - Net equity in own unincorporated business - Mututal funds and investment funds - (Private) Pensions funds - Bonds and other debt securities - Shares and other equity - Life insurance funds -Other financial assets ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Liabilities**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Owner-occupied residence loans - Consumer durable loans (e.g. for vehicles) - Other investment loans (collateralized) - Other loans (e.g. education loans) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.absolute top="70%" left="60%" .textbox .fragment .fade-up} No human, social and cultural capital; No public social security pensions (marketable vs. augmented wealth) ::: ::: {.aside} Source: @oecd:2013 ::: ## HFCS sampling and underreporting ::: {.incremental style="font-size:1.8rem"} - Target population in Austria 2021: [4 million households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Gross sample in HFCS 2021: [6,300 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Realized interviews: [2,293 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Response rate in HFCS 2021: [39%]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Residual: [refused interviews]{.marker-hl}, invalid addresses, households not available, etc. ::: ::: {.absolute bottom="5%" left="10%" width="800px" .textbox .fragment .fade-up style="font-size:1.7rem;padding:0.5rem 1rem;" .altlist} - Response refusal correlates with wealth and is highest at the top [@vermeulen:2016] - Wealthy households own a greater number of assets and miss some components more easily [@kennickell:1999] ::: ## Upstream strategy against underreporting: Oversampling {.smaller} - Undercoverage and Underreporting - Oversampling is crucial for wealth surveys - Oversampling in HFCS 2021: :belgium: :cyprus: :de: :estonia: :es: :it: :finland: :fr: :greece: :croatia: :hungary: :ireland: :latvia: :lithuania: :luxembourg: :portugal: :slovakia: - No oversampling: :austria: :czech_republic: :malta: :netherlands: :slovenia: - How does oversampling work? - External personal wealth data (:fr: :es: :lithuania:) - List of streets with high-income people (:de:) - Income tax data (:luxembourg: 20% of the sample from top 10% earners) - Regions with higher average income or house prices (:belgium: :greece:) - Electricity consumption (:cyprus:) ## Downstream strategy against underreporting: Pareto estimation {.smaller} - Pareto-Distribution is a sensible approximation to the distribution of large wealth - Two parameters: - Threshold for "large" wealth $m$ - Pareto-Index $\alpha$ $$P_i(x_i) = Pr(X_i \leqslant x_i) = 1 - \left(\frac{m_i}{x_i}\right)^{\alpha_i}$$ $$\forall ~\text{implicates} ~i = 1...5 \wedge x_i \geqslant m_i$$ ::: {.fragment .fade-in} [A smaller $\alpha$ means greater inequality. Empirically, $\alpha$ often is around 1.5 for wealth.]{.bubble .bubble-bottom-left .absolute top="30%" right="0%" style="--bubcol: var(--bubcol-red);max-width:350px;font-size:1.2rem;"} ::: ::: {.aside} Reading recommendation: @gabaix:2016 ::: ## European Rich List Database (ERLDB) and HFCS {.smaller} ![](img/rlmap_col.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} ::: {.aside} Source: @disslbacher:2020 ::: ## Cumulative density function of wealth in Germany {.smaller} ![](img/ccdf_pareto.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} ::: {.aside} Source: @disslbacher:2020 ::: ## New data source: Distributional wealth accounts (DWA) {.smaller} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/dwa-1.png){width=960} ::: {.aside} Source: DWA, ECB ::: # Wealth distribution in Austria
![](../../data/img/avatar_laptop.png){width=250}
::: footer ::: ## Net wealth distribution in Austria ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/waffle-1.png){width=960} ## Self-positioning in the wealth distribution {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/selfass-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: . . . ::: {.altlist style="font-size:1.3rem;text-align:center"} - Correct positioning of households in the richest decile: [0]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Average estimated decile in the richest decile: [6]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Average estimated decile in the poorest decile: [3]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} ::: ::: {.aside} Note: for animated version, see [here](https://twitter.com/matschnetzer/status/1091679602265780225) ::: ## Gender wealth gap in Austria { .smaller } ::: {.tbl-classic .tbl-smaller} | | Mean wealth | Mean GWG (in €) | Mean GWG (in %) | Median Wealth | Median GWG (in €) | Median GWG (in %) | |-|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:| | *All respondents* | | Couples | 356,553 | | | 173,683 | | | Male | 207,485 | 58,417 | 28 | 82,285 | 13,862 | 17 | | Female | 149,068 | | | 68,422 | | | | *Male respondent* | | Male | 270,307 | 110,995 | 41.1 | 99,347 | 27,085 | 27.3 | | Female | 159,312 | | | 72,262 | | | *Female respondent* | | Male | 138,830 | 957 | 0.7 | 63,825 | −1,395 | -2.2 | | Female | 137,873 | | | 65,220 | | : {tbl-colwidths="[20,13,13,13,13,13,13]"} ::: ::: {.aside} Note: The respondent in HFCS is the financially most knowledgeable person who is best informed about the household's finances.
Source: @rehm:2022 ::: ## Migrant wealth gap in Austria {.smaller} ::: {.tbl-classic .tbl-smaller} | | Mean wealth | Mean MWG (in €) | Mean MWG (in %) | Median Wealth | Median MWG (in €) | Median MWG (in %) | |-|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:| | Natives | 165,730 | | | 59,001 | | | *Migrants* | | Total | 98,007 | 67,723 | 41 | 15,931 | 43,070 | 73 | | 1st generation | 63,001 | 102,729 | 62 | 9,917 | 49,084 | 83 | | 2nd generation | 139,775 | 25,955 | 16 | 32,763 | 26,238 | 44 | | *1st generation migrants only* | | Short stay | 39,598 | 126,132 | 76 | 4,935 | 54,066 | 92 | | Long stay | 86,317 | 79,413 | 48 | 20,196 | 38,805 | 66 | : {tbl-colwidths="[20,13,13,13,13,13,13]"} ::: ::: {.aside} Note: First-generation migrants are distinguished into short (⩽20 years) and long (>20 years) time since arrival in Austria.
Source: @muckenhuber:2022 ::: # Perceptions of wealth inequality
![](../../data/img/avatar_mobile.png){width=250}
::: footer ::: ## Income and wealth inequality across Europe ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/ginis-1.png){width=960} ## Perceptions of fairness in wealth disparities {.smaller} ![](img/incvswealth.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} @schnetzer:2024 ::: ## Private-public wealth gap {.smaller} ![](img/privpubwealth.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: # Scales ![](../../data/img/avatar_point.png){fig-align="center" height=350} ::: footer ::: ## Axes {.medium} [Continuous]{.secfont} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1,2|3,4,5,6"} ggplot(aes(x = life_expectancy, y = poverty_rate)) + geom_point() + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(40, 100), breaks = seq(40, 100, 20), labels = scales::number_format(suffix = "years")) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) ``` ::: [Dates]{.secfont} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(aes(x = year, y = poverty_rate)) + geom_line() + scale_x_date(limits = c(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2024-01-01")), breaks = date_breaks = "2 years", labels = date_labels = "%Y") ``` ::: [Others]{.secfont} [scale_x_discrete(), scale_x_log10(), scale_x_reverse(), scale_x_sqrt(), ...]{.secfont style="font-size:1.5rem;"} ## Colors {.smaller} [Manual]{.secfont} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(aes(x = year, y = poverty_rate, color = country)) + geom_line() + scale_color_manual(values = c("red", "blue", "green")) ``` ::: [Gradient]{.secfont} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(aes(x = gdp, y = life_expectancy, color = poverty_rate)) + geom_point() + scale_color_gradient(low = "green", high = "red", na.value = "gray80") ``` ::: [Brewer]{.secfont} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(aes(x = year, y = poverty_rate, fill = country)) + geom_area() + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") ``` ::: [Others]{.secfont} [scale_color_binned(), scale_color_distiller(), scale_color_grey(), ...]{.secfont style="font-size:1.5rem;"} ## Shape, size and alpha {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tribble(~x, ~y, ~significance, ~gdp, ~continent, 0.5, 0.5, "yes", 140, "Asia", 1.0, 0.5, "yes", 100, "Africa", 1.5, 0.5, "no", 250, "Europe") |> ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y)) + geom_point(aes(alpha = significance, size = gdp, shape = continent)) + scale_alpha_discrete(range = c(0.5, 1), guide = guide_none()) + scale_size_continuous(range = c(5, 12), guide = guide_none()) + scale_shape_manual(values = c(17, 19, 15), guide = guide_legend(title = "Continent", override.aes = list(size = 5))) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/alphaxmpl-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576} ::: ::: ## Guides {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(aes(x = life_expectancy, y = poverty_rate, color = continent)) + geom_point() + scale_color_viridis_d(guide = guide_legend(title.position = "top", title.theme = element_text(size = 2), title.hjust = 0, title.vjust = 0.5, label.position = "bottom", label.hjust = 0, label.vjust = 0.5, keywidth = 2, keyheight = 2, direction = "horizontal", override.aes = list(size = 4), nrow = 1, ncol = 4, byrow = FALSE, reverse = FALSE, ...)) ``` :::
::: {.tbl .tbl-classic} | Scale type | Default guide type | |------------|--------------------| continuous scales for colour/fill aesthetics | colourbar | binned scales for colour/fill aesthetics | coloursteps | position scales (continuous, binned and discrete) | axis | discrete scales (except position scales) | legend | binned scales (except position/colour/fill scales) | bins | : {tbl-colwidths="[50,20]"} ::: ## Bibliography {.bibstyle} :::footer :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
